results.title: Bonds and relationships. Parts 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: David Zweck, Daryl Wayland and Country education Project-Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: A panel led by Peter Couchman, (Don Edgar, Institute of Family Affairs Jenni Strauss and Dr. Christopher Worth, Monash University and Colin Goodwin of Philip Institute) discuss the HSC literature theme which concentrates on the family and the connections which operate within families. In Part 1 the texts “Father and son” by Edmund Gosse and “Long day’s journey into night” by Eugene O’Neill are considered. Covers such topics as the changing mix of families, the stress of being oneself in a family relationship and yet still being part of a family, and the kinds of support available for people facing problems. Part 2 looks at more contemporary issues that affect family relationships. The texts “The Millstone” by Margaret Drabble and “A Very easy death” by Simone de Beauvoir are considered.

results.title: Bonds
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Brickwork”.
This film describes why different types of bonds are used and proceeds to demonstrate various bonds. It explains that “bonding” means to arrange bricks to a definite pattern according to function. A wall in “Flemish” bond is shown and its construction demonstrated in a one brick and a one and a half brick wall. “English” bond is then dealt with followed by “Dutch” bond. English and Flemish garden wall bonds bring the film to a close.

results.title: Bonanza: The Ape. The Savage
results.creator_credit: David Dortort and National Broadcasting Company
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Bonanza”.
The Ape (dir. James P. Yarbrough): Hoss befriends Arnie Gurne - a lumbering, disabled, man who knows how to fight. Hoss, respectful of his physical prowess, puts Arnie to work on the farm. His best intentions backfire however when Hoss is accused of harbouring a criminal after Arnie turns on the object of his affection, saloon girl Sharie, and kills her. A posse is set out to capture the misunderstood Gurne. “The Savage” (dir. James Neilson): Shoshone Indians kill two fur trappers after they enter a sacred burial ground. Of this tribe, two of them cross over the forbidden stone to find the spirit of White Buffalo Woman to save their ailing tribe. When one of them makes contact with her, they discover she is a flesh and blood white woman, not a spirit, and vow to kidnap her and return to the village exposing her mortality. Adam is injured by Indians protecting the woman and finds himself nursed by White Buffalo Woman with whom he falls in love. Cast includes: Dan Blocker, Michael Landon, Lorne Greene, Pernell Roberts.

results.title: Bon Voyage (Captioned)
results.brief_description: Upon the cruise ship “Mara” - bound for Hong Kong out of San Francisco - an oddly assorted group of travellers dine together at the Captain’s table. Here the basis of a developing web of relationships is laid and made all the more intimate and public by the inevitably close world a sea voyage creates. Starring Nigel Havers and Judy Parfitt Based on the original by Noel Coward. Rated: PG

results.title: Bombshell
results.creator_credit: Norie Varga, Margaret Riley, Charles Randolph, Michelle Graham, Beth Kono, Aaron L. Gilbert, Robert Graf, A.J. Dix, Mark Ricker, Charlize Theron, Jay Roach, Colleen Atwood, Endeavor Content, Lionsgate, Creative Wealth Media Finance, Annapurna Pictures, Bron Studios, Denver and Delilah Productions and Lighthouse Management + Media
results.headline_credit: Canada and United States of America, 2019
results.brief_description: Bombshell is a revealing look inside the most powerful and controversial media empire of all time; and the explosive story of the women who brought down the infamous man who created it.

constellations_other.name: Elevator Operator: Up and down, the on-screen gift of elevators
constellations_other.description: Inspired by Courtney Barnett playing an elevator operator in her hit song of the same name, we look at how they're used on-screen for comedy, drama and suspense, with the small, confined boxes forcing characters to physically confront each other.

results.title: Bombs will make the rainbows break
results.creator_credit: Tom Hurwitz, Barbara Zahm and Films Incorporated
results.brief_description: Presents the artwork and writings of many children from the United States and their response to fears about nuclear war. Culminates in a march and demoNstration in Washington where the children’s letters are read aloud in front of the White House.

results.title: Bombay: gateway to India
results.brief_description: This film features the tourist attractions of Bombay and the surrounding district including the India Gate, the city and harbour, the view from Malabar Hill, public buildings, street entertainers, the harbour, and Elephanta Island with its ancient cave temples.
results.description: This film features the tourist attractions of Bombay and the surrounding district including the India Gate, the city and harbour, the view from Malabar Hill, public buildings, street entertainers, the harbour, and Elephanta Island with its ancient cave temples.

results.title: Bombay talkie
results.creator_credit: James Ivory, Ismail Merchant and Merchant Ivory Productions
results.brief_description: An early production from the Merchant/Ivory team, set, as most of their early films were, in India. Starring Jennifer Kendal, Shashi Kapoor and Zia Mohyeddin it tells the story of a bored English woman novelist who destroys the lives of a young Indian film star and a scriptwriter. The intended irony of the melodrama doesn’t quite come off but the story is full of fine marginal details, such as the guru showing his followers colour slides of his conquest of Los Angeles, the plump-bottomed Indian girls performing a dance routine on giant typewriter keys for a Bombay musical and the society life of the Bombay film set.
